Question E Let R be the relation on Z (the set of integers) defined by (x, y)  R iff y = x. a) Provide (i) an ordered pair in R, showing why it belongs to R, and (ii) an ordered pair not in R, showing why it does not belong to R. (Use at least one negative integer in one of the pairs.) b) By doing the appropriate tests, show that R is an equivalence relation. Solution: a) We provide two examples: (i) (1, −1)  R because 1=−1. (1, 2)  R because 12. b) In order to prove that R is an equivalence relation, we have to prove that R is reflexive on Z, symmetric and transitive. (Refer to study guide, p91.) Reflexive: A relation R on A is reflexive on A iff for every x  A, we have (x, x)  R. For all x  Z we have x = x, thus x=x i.e. (x, x)  R and therefore R is reflexive on Z. (Refer to study guide, p75.) 8 Symmetry: A relation R on A is symmetric iff, for all x, y  A, if (x, y)  R then (y, x)  R. This means that for a relation to be symmetric, an ordered pair and its mirror image must both live together in that relation. Goal: to show that whenever (x, y) R, then (y, x) also belongs to R. Suppose (x, y)  R, then x=y i.e. y=x, therefore (y, x)  R. Thus R is symmetric. (Refer to study guide, p 76.) Transitivity: R is transitive iff, for all x, y, z  A, if (x, y)  R and (y, z)  R then (x, z)  R. Goal: to show that whenever (x, y)  R and (y, z)  R then (x, z )  R. Suppose (x, y)  R, then x=y ➀ and suppose (y, z)  R, then y=z. ➁ From ➀ and ➁ it follows that: x=y=z i.e.x=z, therefore (x, z)  R. Thus R is transitive. (Refer to study guide, p 77.) Since R is reflexive, symmetric and transitive it is an equivalence relation. COS1501/102/0/2022 9 Question F Let P and R be relations on A = {1, 2, 3, {1}, {2}, {3}} given by P = {(1, {1}), ({1}, 1), (1, 2), (2, 1)} and R = {(1, {1}), (3, {3}), (2, {2}), ({2}, {2}), ({3}, 3)}. a) Test whether P has the following properties: irreflexive; reflexive; symmetric; antisymmetric; transitive. b) Does R satisfy trichotomy? c) Determine the relations R ￮ R and R ￮ P (i.e. P; R). d) Give the subset T of R where (A, B)  T iff A  B. e) Give a partition B of the set A = { 1, 2, 3, {1}, {2}, {3} }. We provide a counterexample: 1 ≠ {1} and (1, {1})  P, but it is also the case that ({1}, 1)  P. Transitivity: If (x, y)  P and (y, z)  P, is it the case that (x, z)  P? No, R is not transitive. We provide a counterexample: (1, {1})  P, and ({1}, 1)  P, but (1,1)  P. 10 b) Trichotomy: Is it the case for all x, y A, if x ≠ y that (x, y)  R or (y, x)  R? No, R does not satisfy trichotomy, we provide a counterexample: (2, 3)  R and also (3, 2)  R. c) RR: (x, w)  R￮R iff for some y there exist pairs (x, y)  R and (y, w)  R. R = {(1, {1}), (3, {3}), (2, {2}), ({2}, {2}), ({3}, 3)} We have that (2, {2})  R and ({2}, {2})  R, hence (2, {2})  R￮R. Also: (3, {3})  R and ({3}, 3)  R, hence (3, 3)  R￮R. ({3}, 3)  R and (3, {3})  R, hence ({3}, {3})  R￮R. Thus R￮R = { (2, {2}), (3, 3), ({3}, {3}) }. RP: We have that ({1}, 1)  P and (1, {1})  R, hence ({1}, {1})  P;R. Also: (1, 2)  P and (2, {2})  R, hence (1, {2})  P;R. (2, 1)  P and (1, {1})  R, hence (2, {1})  P;R. Thus R￮P = P;R = { ({1}, {1}), (1, {2}), (2, {1})}. d) T: T is a subset of R, so T is also a relation on A. We have (A, B)  T iff A  B. In each ordered pair in T, the first co-ordinate must be a subset of the second co-ordinate. We have T = { ({2}, {2}) }  R. (T only has one member because there is only one case in R where the first co- ordinate is a subset of the second co-ordinate: {2}  {2}.) (Refer to study guide, pp 75-82.) e) Give a partition B of the set A = { 1, 2, 3, {1}, {2}, {3} }. One of the partitions of A is B = {{1, 2}, {3, {1}, {2}, {3}}}. (The parts (i.e. elements) of B are {1, 2} and {3, {1}, {2}, {3}}, and these parts of B are subsets of A.) Why is B a partition of A? (Refer to page 94 of the study guide.)
